revisions.name: backstage
revisions.title: Backstage.io
revisions.body:
Backstage is an open platform for building developer portals. Powered by a centralized software catalog, Backstage restores order to your microservices and infrastructure and enables your product teams to ship high-quality code quickly — without compromising autonomy.

Backstage is an [open-source][GitHub - Backstage project from Spotify with a plug-in architecture allowing for creating custom extensions. It could also assist with OpenAPI adoption.

Backstage could fix several issues

  • Standardizing Projects/Services

  • Clear ownership

  • Standardizing documentation

  • Service Catalog

  • Software Catalog

  • Backstage Upgrade Helper for upgrading between versions of Backstage

  • GitHub - Backstage Releases

  • YouTube - Data Visualizations in Backstage

revisions.name: calver
revisions.title: Calendar Versioning (CalVer)
revisions.body:
Calendar Versioning is typically appropriate when SemVer is not. It allows a grouping of related projects together (each with their own semantic version) with a combined version number that makes more sense and removes confusion.

CalVer is a versioning convention based on your project's release calendar, instead of arbitrary numbers.

revisions.name: confluent-control-center
revisions.title: Confluent Control Center (c3)
revisions.body:
Confluent Control Center is a UI for Kafka. It doesn't work correctly, overpromises, and is generally unmaintained by Confluent. It does not provide basic functionality in other products like Kowl, Red Panda's Console, or Kafka-UI.

Deal killers for c3

  • No cross-parition searching
  • No schema visibility
  • RBAC is not robust enough to create meaningful roles
  • No link between topics and consumers
  • Endless scroll for message results (this is bad, pagination is preferred due to the nature of the results)
  • No robust search options (only simple text search)
  • Creates a null consumer group when searching for messages
  • Sometimes it does not deserialize messages

revisions.name: dev-containers
revisions.title: Development Containers
revisions.body:
A Development Container (or Dev Container for short) allows you to use a container as a full-featured development environment. It can be used to run an application, to separate tools, libraries, or runtimes needed for working with a codebase, and to aid in continuous integration and testing. Dev containers can be run locally or remotely, in a private or public cloud.

VSCode supports development inside of Dev Containers using VSCode Dev Containers but this unfortunately relies heavily on Docker Desktop. There are workarounds, but these workarounds do not provide the seamless Dev Container expecience within VSCode that Docker Desktop does.

The Dev Containers spec and examples are developed in the open at GitHub - Development Containers.

Source code for the VSCode devcontainer definitions can be found at GitHub - VSCode Dev Containers.

See also [Reproducible Development with Devcontainers][Reproducible Development with Devcontainers]

revisions.name: event-modeling
revisions.title: Event Modeling
revisions.body:
Event Modeling is a method of describing systems using an example of how information has changed within them over time. Specifically this omits transient details and looks at what is durably stored and what the user sees at any particular point in time. These are the events on the timeline that form the description of the system.

This technique may sound simliar to Event Storming but there are several important [differences]Event Storming vs Event Modeling].

Event Sourcing should be used in conjunction with Event Modling to get the benefits of Event Driven Architecture.

revisions.name: gnu-parallel
revisions.title: GNU Parallel
revisions.body: GNU Parallel is a shell tool for executing jobs in parallel using one or more computers. A job can be a single command or a small script that has to be run for each of the lines in the input. The typical input is a list of files, a list of hosts, a list of users, a list of URLs, or a list of tables. A job can also be a command that reads from a pipe. GNU parallel can then split the input and pipe it into commands in parallel.

revisions.name: island-of-agility
revisions.title: Island of Agility
revisions.body:
From Why You Might Need an Island of Agility

An island of agility is a team of teams working independently of the rest of the organization to the extent it can ignore guidance or direction from the c-suite. An island of agility is not a function/department operating agility in a silo. The island's scope needs to be significant enough to get the focus and commitment to succeed. Perhaps it's working on the organization's second or third most urgent thing. Maybe it's working on a pivot or new product development. In this case, it would not be entangled with current product development.

revisions.name: kafka-connect
revisions.title: Kafka Connect
revisions.body:
Kafka Connect provides an abstraction over the consumer/producer API's of Kafka. This allows team to use a Connect Plug-In without writing any client code. Teams would be responsible for creating the connector configuration. For example, if a team wanted to simply replicate data from a database onto a Kafka topic with little to no data manipulation, then Kafka Connect would be an excellent use case. Although Connect provides some data manipulation abilities though the use of SMT's, it is not meant for advanced logic.

Kafka Connect is a tool for scalably and reliably streaming data between Apache Kafka and other systems. It makes it simple to quickly define connectors that move large collections of data into and out of Kafka. Kafka Connect can ingest entire databases or collect metrics from all your application servers into Kafka topics, making the data available for stream processing with low latency. An export job can deliver data from Kafka topics into secondary storage and query systems or into batch systems for offline analysis.

Confluent Kafka Connect offers their version of Kafka Connect. Confluent offers a fully-managed Cloud-based Kafka Connect which required zero management of the Connect cluster. They also offer a version which can be self-managed in a Kubernetes cluster, for instance. The self-managed version requires additional monitoring and obervabiliy to be in place to ensure uptime, but it also offers more flexibility in deployment strategies and plug-in options not available via Confluent Hub.

revisions.name: kasm-workspaces
revisions.title: Kasm Workspaces
revisions.body:
Kasm Workspaces allows you to run GUI apps in a container for desktop use. They also have paid cloud options.

If you like to dork out on getting GUI apps to run inside containers, you might be interested in Kasm Workspaces.

You can start a Linux Desktop in the browser using the Kasm Desktop image by running

docker run --rm  -it --shm-size=512m -p 6901:6901 -e VNC_PW=password kasmweb/desktop:1.10.0

Then browse to https://localhost:6901

  • User : kasm_user
  • Password: password

But I prefer to run Doom

docker run --rm  -it --shm-size=512m -p 6901:6901 -e VNC_PW=password kasmweb/doom:1.10.0

If you run into the NET::ERR_CERT_INVALID in Chrome on MacOS there's a secret passphrase built into the error page. Just make sure the page is selected (click anywhere on the screen) and type thisisunsafe. The page should then magically proceed.

A list of all Kasm images can be found on Docker Hub as well as listed here.

Image sources are in GitHub - Kasm.

revisions.name: ksqldb
revisions.title: ksqlDB
revisions.body:
ksqlDB is an abstraction over the KStreams and KTables interfaces of Kafka which allows for full streaming paradigms to be declared and deployed using a SQL-like syntax without the need for developing a full code-based client. It does require that a ksqlDB cluster be running which can be self-hosted or fully-managed such as the one in Confluent Cloud.

ksqlDB enables you to build event streaming applications leveraging your familiarity with relational databases. Three categories are foundational to building an application: collections, stream processing, and queries.

A Monorepo is a specific Trunk-Based Development implementation where the organization in question puts its source for all applications/services/libraries/frameworks into one trunk and forces developers to commit together in that trunk - atomically.

Look into tooling to manage Monorepos if this technology is being considered.Nx is one example of such tools with Monorepo support.

revisions.title: Mutexes in dotnet
revisions.body: You can use a Mutex object to provide exclusive access to a resource. The Mutex class uses more system resources than the Monitor class, but it can be marshalled across application domain boundaries, it can be used with multiple waits, and it can be used to synchronize threads in different processes. For a comparison of managed synchronization mechanisms, see Overview of Synchronization Primitives.

revisions.name: node-red
revisions.title: Node-RED
revisions.body:
Node-RED is a programming tool for wiring together hardware devices, APIs and online services in new and interesting ways.

It provides a browser-based editor that makes it easy to wire together flows using the wide range of nodes in the palette that can be deployed to its runtime in a single-click.

Because Node-RED is pluggable, there are quite a few flows available in the Node-RED Library.

Node-RED can also do website change monitoring. For instane the Node-RED - Detect Change subflow monitor a website for changes on a set interval.

See Node-RED - Creating your first flow to get started.

revisions.name: open-api
revisions.title: OpenAPI
revisions.body:
The OpenAPI Specification defines a standard, programming language-agnostic interface description for REST APIs, which allows both humans and computers to discover and understand the capabilities of a service without requiring access to source code, additional documentation, or inspection of network traffic. When properly defined via OAS, a consumer can understand and interact with the remote service with a minimal amount of implementation logic. Similar to what interface descriptions have done for lower-level programming, the OAS removes guesswork in calling a service.

There are also a wide variety of OpenAPI Tools available.

revisions.name: pixabay
revisions.title: Pixabay
revisions.body:
Pixabay is a vibrant community of creatives, sharing rroyalty-free HD photos and stock images, new illustration vectors, high-quality videos, popular animated GIFs and best audio music that are free to download. All contents are released under the Pixabay License, which makes them safe to use without attribution - even for commercial purposes.

License

Per the Pixabay - License

What is allowed?

  • All content (e.g. images, videos, music) on Pixabay can be used for free for commercial and noncommercial use across print and digital, except in the cases mentioned in "What is not allowed".
  • Attribution is not required. Giving credit to the artist or Pixabay is not necessary but is always appreciated by our community.
  • You can make modifications to content from Pixabay. What is not allowed?

This section only applies to media users and not to the appropriate artists.

  • Don't redistribute or sell Pixabay content on other stock or wallpaper platforms.
  • Don't sell unaltered copies of content, e.g. don't sell an exact copy of a stock photo as a poster, print or on a physical product.
  • Don't portray identifiable people in a bad light or in a way that is offensive.
  • Don't use content with identifiable persons or brands to create a misleading association with a product or service.

revisions.name: semver
revisions.title: Semantic Versioning 2.0.0 (SemVer)
revisions.body:
Semantic Versioning 2.0.0

Summary

Given a version number MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH, increment the:

MAJOR version when you make incompatible API changes
MINOR version when you add functionality in a backwards > compatible manner
PATCH version when you make backwards compatible bug fixes

Additional labels for pre-release and build metadata are > available as extensions to the MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH format.

revisions.name: spectral
revisions.title: Spectral
revisions.body:
spectral is an API style-guide linter.

Spectral can be used as a generic ruleset engine on any JSON or YAML data, but was built with OpenAPI, AsyncAPI, and JSON Schema in mind. Spectral rules can either target API descriptions themselves to improve their quality, or they can target the underlying API, allowing you to cover everything from OpenAPI models naming conventions, to enforcing rules like banning the use of integers in the URLs.

revisions.name: steemit
revisions.title: steemit
revisions.body:
Steemit is a blockchain-based social media Dapp (decentralized application) that creates communities where users are rewarded for sharing their voice. It's a new kind of attention economy.

Copyright

Copyright is critical when choosing a blogging or vlogging platform. Both Medium and YouTube have clear explanations of ownership. steemit is no different.

Per the Steemit - Terms of Service

You retain ownership of and responsibility for Content you create or own ("Your Content"). If you're posting anything you did not create yourself or do not own the rights to, you agree that you are responsible for any Content you post; that you will only submit Content that you have the right to post; and that you will fully comply with any third-party licenses relating to Content you post.

Licensing Content

Follow Licensing Steemit Content to ensure that your work is properly licensed and copyrighted to clearly identify ownership of your own content.

Attribution

Follow the Copyright Discussion to make sure you properly credit other content that gets included in your post.

The linked post also covers sites where Cretive Commons media can be found.

Security

When posing your own images, ensure the exif data is stripped.

revisions.name: strimzi
revisions.title: Strimzi
revisions.body:
Avoid use of Strimzi. It is riddled with issues and bugs. It also introduces a race condition in the way it attempts to ensure desired state when deploying topics via Strimzi. The unsafe choices limits the deployment mechanism to pipeline-only using Strimzi. This slows some dev environment practices. It also means that manually intervening in a prod environment is also problematic. In a worst-case scenario (which has happened), Strimzi's race conditions can result in irreoverable data loss through the unintended deletion of topics.

Strimzi provides a way to run an Apache Kafka cluster on Kubernetes in various deployment configurations.

revisions.name: team-cognitive-load-assessment
revisions.title: Team Cognitive Load Assessment
revisions.body:
A Team Cognitive Load Assessment measures the impact of how difficult or easy it is for teams to build, test, and maintain services they are responsible for.

Taken from the book Team Topologies which provides a model for organizational design and team interaction.

  • GitHub - Team Cognitive Load Assessment
  • Google Doc - Team Cognitive Load Assessment
  • Team Topologies
Engineering Experience Feedback

With this survey we want to assess how easy/hard you find it to build, test, run and support the services your team responsible for. 

Note: answers will not be used in any kind of evaluation/review/appraisal context. Results will be aggregated at the team level.
 
How is the experience of building your services? *
Things to consider: is building a clear and repeatable task? Is it fast "enough"? What happens when builds fail? Are failures easy to diagnose?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

How is the experience of testing your services? *
Things to consider: is testing a clear and repeatable task? Is it fast "enough"? What happens when tests fail? Are failures easy to diagnose? Are test environments adequate? Are test environments easy to access/spin up/clean up/inject test data?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

How is the experience of deploying your services? *
Things to consider: are deployments a clear and repeatable task? Do you know what the deployment strategy is? What happens when deployments fail? Is it possible and straightforward to rollback a failed deployment? Do you have access to the necessary logs to understand why a deployment failed and/or its current status?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

How is the experience of operating your services? *
Things to consider: do you know how each service is being monitored and have access to the data? Are adequate alerts (few false positives) being sent? Are logs and information accessible and easy to find? Are data flows across services relatively easy to follow?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

How is the experience of being on-call for your services? *
Things to consider: do you know what's the incident response procedure? Do you feel you have enough experience (either real or simulated) to deal with incidents without high levels of stress? Do you know who to reach out for help during an incident when you're on-call? Would you be anxious about a 3am outage? What about an incident in a service that hasn't been modified for months or years?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

How is the experience of dealing with health industry regulations and compliance? *
Things to consider: do you feel you have sufficient awareness to raise questions on changes that might require compliance oversight or at least a quick debrief? Are you confident that you know which industry regulations are of concern for your services? If yes, do you feel that this knowledge is being refreshed often enough?
Very poor
1
2
3
4
5
Very good

Would you like to comment on your overall engineering experience?

revisions.name: tech-radar
revisions.title: Tech Radar
revisions.body:
The ThoughtWorks Tech Radar provides a way to visualize technologies that a company may want to adopt or steer away from. Technologies are not simply software. Technologies include patterns, tools, platforms, techniques, languages, and frameworks.

Each item is shown on a circular dashboard and will fall into one of four quadrants

  • techniques
  • tools
  • platforms
  • languages-and-frameworks

There are concentric rings in the cirular dashboard. The closer to the center of the cicle, the more viable the technology is to the company.

  • adopt
  • trial
  • assess
  • hold

A review is done yearly to assess technologies and the results are shared with the company to allow engineers a clear insight as to the direction of technologies into the company at a glance.

The Tech Radar is not an "Approved Technologies" page.

The Tech Radar can also be a great place for new employees to go to get info on the tech stack.

A few links on Tech Radars

  • https://github.com/AOEpeople/techradar
  • https://github.com/zalando/tech-radar
  • https://github.com/bdargan/techradar
  • https://github.com/AOEpeople/aoe_technology_radar
  • Thoughtworks Technology Radar
  • Build your own radar
  • BYOR GitHub Repo
  • Example Spreadsheet

revisions.name: teller
revisions.title: Teller
revisions.body:
Possibly use this for creating Kafka API secrets at runtime instead of generating conf files.

Works with Azure Key Vault and 1Password.

Teller - the open-source universal secret manager for developers

Instead of custom scripts, tokens in your .zshrc files, visible EXPORTs in your bash history, misplaced .env.production files and more around your workstation -- just use teller and connect it to any vault, key store, or cloud service you like (Teller support Hashicorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, Google Secret Manager, and many more).

revisions.name: terraform
revisions.title: Terraform
revisions.body:
Terraform is an open source IaC tool with optional proprietary components such as Terrafom Workspaces.

HashiCorp Terraform is an infrastructure as code tool that lets you define both cloud and on-prem resources in human-readable configuration files that you can version, reuse, and share. You can then use a consistent workflow to provision and manage all of your infrastructure throughout its lifecycle. Terraform can manage low-level components like compute, storage, and networking resources, as well as high-level components like DNS entries and SaaS features.

revisions.name: unsplash
revisions.title: Unsplash
revisions.body:
Unsplash

Beautiful, free images gifted by the world’s most generous community of photographers. Better than any royalty free or stock photos.

License

Per the Unsplash - License

Unsplash photos are made to be used freely. Our license reflects that.

  • All photos can be downloaded and used for free
  • Commercial and non-commercial purposes
  • No permission needed (though attribution is appreciated!)

What is not permitted 👎

  • Photos cannot be sold without significant modification.
  • Compiling photos from Unsplash to replicate a similar or competing service.

revisions.name: warewolf
revisions.title: Warewolf
revisions.body:
Warewolf allows developers to use a low-code, visual, flow-based, drag and drop environment to design and create microservices, and then call those microservices from directly within their applications. The end result is months of programming accomplished in days and a total revolution in how we think about and use the SOA framework.

  • Warewolf - How-To-Compile

revisions.name: wiremock
revisions.title: WireMock
revisions.body:
WireMock is an HTTP mock server. At its core it is web server that can be primed to serve canned responses to particular requests (stubbing) and that captures incoming requests so that they can be checked later (verification).

The flexible tool for building mock APIs.

Create stable development environments, isolate yourself from flakey 3rd parties and simulate APIs that don't exist yet.

revisions.name: wireshark
revisions.title: Wireshark
revisions.body: Wireshark is the world’s foremost and widely-used network protocol analyzer. It lets you see what’s happening on your network at a microscopic level and is the de facto (and often de jure) standard across many commercial and non-profit enterprises, government agencies, and educational institutions. Wireshark development thrives thanks to the volunteer contributions of networking experts around the globe and is the continuation of a project started by Gerald Combs in 1998.

  • access files from one WSL 2 distro/image in another one
  • Manual installation steps for older versions of WSL

revisions.name: yunohost
revisions.title: YunoHost
revisions.body:
With YunoHost you can quickly spin up new servers and try out software.

YunoHost is an operating system aiming for the simplest administration of a server, and therefore democratize self-hosting, while making sure it stays reliable, secure, ethical and lightweight. It is a copylefted libre software project maintained exclusively by volunteers. Technically, it can be seen as a distribution based on Debian GNU/Linux and can be installed on many kinds of hardware.

revisions.name: zed-attack-proxy
revisions.title: Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP)
revisions.body: The OWASP Zed Attack Proxy (ZAP) is one of the world’s most popular free security tools and is actively maintained by a dedicated international team of volunteers. It can help you automatically find security vulnerabilities in your web applications while you are developing and testing your applications. It's also a great tool for experienced pentesters to use for manual security testing.
